review.title: A Logical Study of Partial Entailment
review.abstract: We introduce a novel logical notion--partial entailment--to propositional logic. In contrast with classical entailment, that a formula P partially entails another formula Q with respect to a background formula set \Gamma intuitively means that under the circumstance of \Gamma, if P is true then some "part" of Q will also be true. We distinguish three different kinds of partial entailments and formalize them by using an extended notion of prime implicant. We study their semantic properties, which show that, surprisingly, partial entailments fail for many simple inference rules. Then, we study the related computational properties, which indicate that partial entailments are relatively difficult to be computed. Finally, we consider a potential application of partial entailments in reasoning about rational agents.

metadata.title: A Logical Study of Partial Entailment

sections.heading: 4.1 Formula-Variable Independence
sections.text: Lang et al. (2003) defined a concept of formula-variable independence between a formula and a group of atoms. Roughly speaking, a formula is independent of one group of atoms if the formula can be rewritten to another in which no atoms from the group of atoms are mentioned. Definition 7 (Lang et al., 2003) A formula F is variably independent of a group of variables if there is a formula G which is | = F ↔ G and atom (G) х V =.As Lang et al. (2003) have shown, the notion of formula-variable independence coincides with the notions of influence and relevance of a formula for a group of atoms introduced by Boutilier (1994).

sections.heading: 4.2 Other Forms of Relevance
sections.text: Lakemeyer also introduced other forms of relevance, including strict relevance, explanatory relevance and relevance between two facts (Lakemeyer, 1997).Definition 8 (Lakemeyer, 1997) A formula F is strictly relevant to a set V of atoms if each prime number implied by F contains at least one atom of V. The following sentence shows that strict relevance can also be reformulated by implicit and weak partial relevance. Definition 16 Let F be a formula and V = {x1,..., xn} a set of atoms. The following statements are equivalent.1. F is strictly relevant to V.2.

sections.heading: 4.3 Relevance between Formulas
sections.text: As Lakemeyer (1997) has pointed out, it is interesting to reconsider the relevance between formulas in relation to a background theory. Here, we propose a definition of the relevance between two formulas in relation to a background theory by implicitly using prime. Definition 10 A formula P is relevant to a formula Q in relation to a formula set, provided that there is a prime implicit π of P w.r.t. and a prime implicit π of Q w.r.t. The definition 10 is very similar to the definition of weak partial entanglement (see definition 4). The main difference between these two definitions is that weak partial entanglement is defined by a "style," while relevance is defined by a "style." More specifically, in the former definition, we demand that "for all" prime implicators of P w.r.t. a "normal" implication of P w.r.t. in relation to the same "formula," an implicit version of Q does not exist. "

sections.heading: 4.4 Novelty and Novelty-Based Independence
sections.text: The concept of novelty (Marquis, 1991) is defined between two formulas in relation to a formula that is also defined as new. (Definition 11 (Marquis, 1991) A formula P is new positive (new negative) in relation to another formula Q in relation to a formula that consists of two formulas, namely novelty-based independence (also known as separability, see Levesque, 1998) between two formulas based on novelty (Lang, Liberatore, & Marquis, 2002). Definition 12 (Lang et al., 2002) Two formulas P and Q are (novelty-based) independent iff P is not new negative in relation to Q w.r.t. > Intuitively P means that P is new in relation to Q w.r.t. means that the addition of new information P has an effect on the theory.

sections.heading: 4.5 Probabilistic Positive Relevance
sections.text: Another approach to formalizing a certain kind of usefulness is probabilistic positive relevance (Zhou & Chen, 2006), which is based on probability distributions; the basic idea of positive relevance is that a formula P is positively relevant to a different formula Q in terms of a background formula that is defined for all probability distributions Pr, Pr (Q), Pr (Q), Pr (Q), and Pr (P). Although positive relevance is similar to partial consequences and the probability distribution is strongly related to the prime number (Lang et al., 2002), the underlying intuition and semantic properties of positive relevance and partial consequences differ significantly from each other. Thus, for example, according to the definition of positive relevance by Zhou and Chen (2006), x-y is positively relevant to x. However, x-y is not (weak, strong) partially connected to x.

sections.heading: 4.6 Partial Satisfaction of a CNF
sections.text: The term "partial satisfaction" is also used for the satisfaction of a subset of a set of clauses (Lieberherr & Specker, 1981; Ka � ppeli & Scheder, 2007).A CNF formula (i.e. a combination of clauses) is referred to as k-satisfactory if each subformula containing at most k-clauses is satisfactory.Although the term "partial satisfaction" is used for both k-satisfaction and subsequences, it represents different intuitive meanings.For the former, "part" means a subformula (i.e. the set of clauses), while for the latter it means a subset of a prime number of a formula. Therefore, partial consequences and k-satisfaction are essentially irrelevant. Furthermore, k-satisfaction refers only to a certain formula (CNF), while subconditions refer to the relationship between two formulas (w.r.t. a background theory).

sections.heading: 5. Partial Goal Satisfaction
sections.text: If this is not successful, the agents would decide to wait and do nothing. This idea is usually formalized by applying classic action instead of just waiting, in which these actions should be "partly" the agent's goal "partly" satisfactory. "Partly, we believe in the real world we live in. Under the situation, it is sometimes useful for the agents to do something" toward "their goals, instead of just waiting for these actions to be" partly "the agent's goal as rational candidates. Partly, we believe in the real world we live in. Example 6 Let's consider an example of Laura wanting milk and cereals as her breakfast. There are only three options available on the breakfast menu.Choice1 Only milk is offered. Choice2 Milk and bread are offered. Choice3 Only bread is offered. Due to the current information, none of these decisions fully satisfies Laura's goal.

sections.heading: 6. Concluding Remarks
sections.text: We distinguished three different types of sub-sequences (see Table 1) based on the concept of implicit prime number. Results show that the properties of sub-sequences are difficult to grasp because many simple sequences do not apply. We also examined the computational complexity of sub-sequences (see Tables 4 and 5). The results of the complexity are surprising and interesting. For example, the verification of strong sub-sequences is complete even when the background theory is empty. This indicates that the definitions of sub-sequences appear simple, but it is not easy to calculate them. We showed that the terms of sub-sequences can serve as formulae of sub-sequences for the satisfaction of sub-sequences, even if the background theory is empty. This indicates that the definitions of sub-sequences appear simple, but it is not easy to calculate them.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: Some preliminary findings of this paper have been published (Zhou & Chen, 2004; Zhou et al., 2008). We are grateful to Xiaoping Chen and Leon van der Torre for their suggestions and contributions to this paper. We are also grateful to Jerome Lang for his valuable comments on an earlier draft of this paper, and we would like to thank the anonymous reviewer for their valuable comments as well. Authors were partially supported by an Australian Research Council.

The idea of partial satisfaction of goals has been discussed elsewhere in the AI literature (Haddawy & Hanks, 1992; Smith, 2004; Do, Benton, van den Briel, & Kambhampati, 2007).
One approach is so called partial satisfaction planning (Smith, 2004; Do et al., 2007).
One approach is so called partial satisfaction planning (Smith, 2004; Do et al., 2007).

Another approach is due to Haddawy and Hanks (1992). In their approach, the agents’ goals are represented as groups of candidate goals and each of them is associated with a real number between [0, 1] to represent the degree of chances of satisfying a goal.

This can also be proved in a similar way to the techniques introduced by Marquis (2000) for proving the DP completeness for the corresponding decision problem of prime implicate (see Marquis, 2000, Proposition 3.

In fact, the hardness result also follows from the Σ2 completeness of checking relevance in abductive reasoning (see Eiter & Gottlob, 1995, Thm. 4.11). For LAPR(Γ, P, l), the membership can be shown by the following algorithm, which determines whether l is not in all prime implicants of P w.r.t. Γ: 1. guess a literal set π; 2. check if π is a prime implicant of P w.r.t. Γ; 3. if yes, check if l is not in π. According to the above result for prime implicant checking, this problem is in Σ2 . Thus, the original problem is in Π2 . For harness, we can prove it in a similar way to the above proof for the Σ2 hardness of LEPR(Γ, P, l). Indeed, one can prove that ∃X∀Y P iff x is in one of the elements of PI(Γ, F ), where Γ = {¬(x ∧ z ∧ P ∧ (y1 ∨ · · · ∨ yk))}, F = x ∧ z ∧ P ∧ ¬(y1 ∨ · · · ∨ yk) ∨ ¬x ∧ ¬z ∧ (¬y1 ∨ · · · ∨ ¬yk), where x and z are two new atoms. Moreover, x is in one of the elements of PI(Γ, F ) iff ¬x is not in all of the elements in PI(Γ, F ) since every element in PI(Γ, F ) contains either x or ¬x. This shows that determining whether a literal is not in all prime implicants of a formula w.r.t. a formula set is Σ2 hard. It follows that LAPR(Γ, P, l) is Π P 2 hard. For WPE(Γ, P, Q), the Π2 hardness follows directly from Proposition 12. The Σ P 2 hardness can be implied from the hardness proof of the Σ2 hardness of LEPR(Γ, P, l) by noticing that the only prime implicant of x w.r.t. Γ is {x} itself. For the membership, let us first consider the following algorithm, which determines whether P does not weakly partially entail Q w.r.t. Γ: 1. compute all the literals which occur at least in one of the prime implicants of Q w.r.t. Γ; 2. check whether there is a prime implicant of P w.r.t. Γ, which does not contain any of the literals computed in step 1. According to above result for the Σ2 hardness of LEPR(Γ, P, l), step 1 requires linear calls to a Σ2 oracle. In addition, step 2 requires only one recall to a Σ2 oracle based on the results obtained in step 1. To do this, we just need to guess a consistent literal set, and to check if it is a prime implicant of P w.r.t. Γ and contains no literals computed from step 1. This algorithm can be converted to a Σ2 -tree, in which the root is corresponding to the Σ2 call for step 2, and its children are corresponding to the linear Σ2 calls in step 1 for computing those literals. Thus, according the Σ P 2 -tree techniques introduced by Gottlob (1995), WPE(Γ, P, Q) is in ∆3 [O(log n)].

metadata.abstractText: We introduce a novel logical notion–partial entailment–to propositional logic. In contrast with classical entailment, that a formula P partially entails another formula Q with respect to a background formula set Γ intuitively means that under the circumstance of Γ, if P is true then some “part” of Q will also be true. We distinguish three different kinds of partial entailments and formalize them by using an extended notion of prime implicant. We study their semantic properties, which show that, surprisingly, partial entailments fail for many simple inference rules. Then, we study the related computational properties, which indicate that partial entailments are relatively difficult to be computed. Finally, we consider a potential application of partial entailments in reasoning about rational agents.
